snippet.textDisplay: I wish there was a better tutorial for this game. The hints it does give you aren‚Äôt really the best and they were really easily forgotten. I think it tells you to do things, but not really how and it doesn‚Äôt give you much of a chance to try out what you learn. I just started recently and almost quit forever I‚Äôm gonna be honest. For my first soulslike it had been ROUGH until I decided to give it a really fair shot and look up videos and tutorials on my own time. Honestly I‚Äôm a little disappointed that I had to, but I‚Äôm glad I did.
snippet.textOriginal: I wish there was a better tutorial for this game. The hints it does give you aren‚Äôt really the best and they were really easily forgotten. snippet.textDisplay: A video every game journalist should watch
snippet.textOriginal: A video every game journalist should watch

snippet.textDisplay:
1. The symbols should be selfexplaining... Not sure why the game should explain it to us... 

2. The game teached you that your cloathes make a difference... First visit at Hotel, the talk with Antonia should make it clear.

3. It should be obviously that greatswords can block better with the big blade then some tiny daggers, spears, rapiers, etc... Common logic or some gaming experience helps here. 

4. Thats the case in many RPG's. Not sure why so many games split the dialogs. 

5. One of the loading screen texts tells us that we can perfect parry enemy rage attacks üòâ

6. Sure the game doesn't tells you that lying isn't always bad, but it also never claims that lying is bad.
Lying makes you simply more human, because puppets can't lie.

7. Of course do fable arts not consume stamina, thats why it has it own "MP" bars. This should be very obviously even for gaming newbies...
snippet.textOriginal:
1. The symbols should be selfexplaining... Not sure why the game should explain it to us... 

2. The game teached you that your cloathes make a difference... First visit at Hotel, the talk with Antonia should make it clear.

3. It should be obviously that greatswords can block better with the big blade then some tiny daggers, spears, rapiers, etc... Common logic or some gaming experience helps here. 

4. Thats the case in many RPG's. Not sure why so many games split the dialogs. 

5. One of the loading screen texts tells us that we can perfect parry enemy rage attacks üòâ

6. Sure the game doesn't tells you that lying isn't always bad, but it also never claims that lying is bad.
Lying makes you simply more human, because puppets can't lie.

7. Of course do fable arts not consume stamina, thats why it has it own "MP" bars. This should be very obviously even for gaming newbies...

snippet.textDisplay: Using certain gestures in front of NPCs can unlock dialogue. P can also try to pet Spring, the cat in Hotel Krat. She'll be very hissy at first but the more human P becomes, he'll eventually get to pet her and even hold herü•∫
snippet.textOriginal: Using certain gestures in front of NPCs can unlock dialogue. P can also try to pet Spring, the cat in Hotel Krat. She'll be very hissy at first but the more human P becomes, he'll eventually get to pet her and even hold herü•∫

snippet.textDisplay: Not to pile on but yeah everyone else is right, the game tells you literally all of this. Heres a tip you probably dont know. When you have enough ergo to level up the lamp near the reception desk changes to blue. Heres another one for, weapons can be mixed to different handles but some handles dont match well with some blades. Near the top of the weapon in, you can find to boxes that say, slash and strike. For example, having a blade that is a slash type will be debuffed if put onto a handle that is a strike type. When put with a matching type the line is the box will stay straight and not have a debuff. If with a strike type the line will point down and lose some power. One more that isnt really a tip, but a cool detail. Pinocchios nose grows on the painting where if you lie enough, the nose will transform into a weapon that you can take. Also if you lie, Pinocchios shadows nose will grow. You can see it in the hotel really well, if you lie enough you'll see his shadows nose get longer
snippet.textOriginal: Not to pile on but yeah everyone else is right, the game tells you literally all of this. Heres a tip you probably dont know. When you have enough ergo to level up the lamp near the reception desk changes to blue. Heres another one for, weapons can be mixed to different handles but some handles dont match well with some blades. Near the top of the weapon in, you can find to boxes that say, slash and strike. For example, having a blade that is a slash type will be debuffed if put onto a handle that is a strike type. When put with a matching type the line is the box will stay straight and not have a debuff. If with a strike type the line will point down and lose some power. One more that isnt really a tip, but a cool detail. Pinocchios nose grows on the painting where if you lie enough, the nose will transform into a weapon that you can take. Also if you lie, Pinocchios shadows nose will grow. You can see it in the hotel really well, if you lie enough you'll see his shadows nose get longer
